key_title: Key to the species of Pelargonium

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Geraniaceae

source.author: Smith, L.P.; Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Pelargonium
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Smith, L.P.; Walsh, N.G. (1999). Pelargonium. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Plant trailing, climbing or scrambling to 2 m; stems with only retrorse tightly appressed hairs; leaves often peltate
Plants erect herbs, shrubs or subshrubs, if ever creeping only shortly so; stems with some spreading eglandular and/or glandular hairs; leaves never peltate
Leaves deeply ternately dissected or palmatisect, coarsely hirsute to scabrous, strongly fragrant
Leaves shallowly lobed to almost entire (if ever lobed c. halfway to midrib, then lobes rather broad and obtuse); plants villous to pubescent or glabrous, hairs (when present) soft
Plants herbaceous; if petals ever 1 cm long then roots tuberous or extensively rhizomatous; not or hardly odorous, native plants
Plants shrubby, lacking tuberous roots or extensive rhizomes; petals 1 cm long or more; odorous garden-escapes
Petals 12–20 mm long, deep rosy magenta; leaves mostly radical; roots tuberous
Petals to 12 mm long, white to pink; taproots often fleshy but not tuberous, or plants extensively rhizomatous
Fertile stamens 6–8; larger petals 6–12 mm long; plants often ramifying to some extent or extensively rhizomatous
Fertile stamens 3–5 (–6); larger petals 2–6 mm long, or if ever to 8 mm long, then sepals obtuse; plants neither ramifying nor rhizomatous

Indumentum of stems, peduncles and pedicels of mostly long, eglandular hairs (sometimes few sessile or shortly stalked glands present); sepal spur 1–4 (–8) mm long; plants taprooted or rarely, shortly rhizomatous, not colony-forming; leaves radical and cauline; very widespread

Indumentum of stems, peduncles and pedicels of short, dense glandular hairs and eglandular hairs in c. equal proportions, with few or no longer eglandular hairs; sepal spur 1–1.5 mm long; plants extensively rhizomatous, colony-forming; leaves often all or mostly radical; Benambra area
Calyx indumentum short, fine and dense; sepals obtuse (but sometimes minutely apiculate); larger petals c. 8 mm long; rare, alpine fire-follower
Calyx with scattered hairs; sepals acute; larger petals 2–6 mm long; mostly lowland species
Sepal hairs all short, coarse and scattered; nectary spur 0.5–1 mm long; larger petals 2–4 mm long; annual or short-lived perennial (often appearing following fire)
Sepal hairs long, spreading (often mixed with shorter hairs); nectary spur 1–3.5 mm long; larger petals 5–6 mm long; perennial
Stems, peduncles and pedicels lacking glandular hairs
Stems, peduncles and pedicels with glandular hairs
Leaves lobed c. halfway to midrib
Leaves entire or shallowly 3–9-lobed
Leaves strigose with spreading hairs mostly on veins or more or less glabrous, often with a dark ring around the middle above; margins strongly and acutely toothed
Leaves velvety, without a dark ring around the middle above; margins crenate
